div1.head: Report: Yellow Fever in Venezuela, by Henry Rose Carter, [19--]
div1.p:
REPORT
of
YELLOW FEVER
in
VENEZUELA.
--------------------------------------
by
DR. HENRY R. CARTER.
-------------

Findings as definite as those made for Ecuador and Columbia
cannot be made for Venezuela. We found no Yellow Fever in either
Caracas or Maracaibo, in which cities it would probably be most
apt to occur. I think that there is probably none in Venezuela,
but its absence cannot be asserted with the same positiveness as
in Columbia, simply that its presence was not apparent to us.

There was a sharp epidemic centering in Caracas in 1911,
beginning in 1910 and running on into 1912, and with some deaths -
7 - reported in Caracas in 1914. Deaths were reported in other
towns in communication with Caracas during this time, and in
Maracaibo prior to this time.

An examination of the mortuary records of Caracas from the
latter part of 1910 to date does not show any Yellow Fever in
1915 or 1916. It does however show a small number of deaths
from the diagnoses quite frequently used for Yellow Fever when
that disease is not recognized.

Practically all of those cases were examined into and in
no case did Guiteras or myself think they were Yellow Fever.
In one case, however, the diagnosis “Billious Remittent Fever”
was used to conceal the diagnosis of Yellow Fever, which the
physician believed was the cause of death - we think on
insufficient grounds.

A few cases, no deaths, were heard of in Caracas, Villa
Cura, and Maracaibo during this year. In two of those which
were described to us, one in Caracas and one in Villa Cura,
the clinical history was that of Yellow Fever. In neither
case, on account of certain features of association or en-
vironment, did we concur in the diagnosis of these cases.

Only one of these cases, out of four, had been reported to
the Health Authorities. There was not the slightest intention
to conceal the existence of the disease - no secret was made of
it, and one case was recorded as Yellow Fever on the Hospital
Records. It was simply carelessness - neglect to report. The
tendency is rather to make a positive diagnosis of Yellow Fever
in doubtful cases than the contrary.

I have said that I think there is probably no Yellow
Fever in Venezuela, yet in view, First, of its recent presence
there in considerable amount in 1912, if not 1914; Second, the
small amount of the population susceptible to Yellow Fever in
many of the towns liable to it, making it difficult to discover
the disease; Third, the existence of reports of Yellow Fever in
some places; Fourth, the fact that all cases believed to be Yellow
Fever by their Medical Attendants are not reported to the Health
Authorities, it is not improbable that there may be infection
from the epidemic of 1911 & 1912 yet lingering in some communi-
ties. It must also be noted however, that the second factor
named above also tends to increase the chance of the prompt
spontaneous elimination of Yellow Fever by the failure of the
human host.

It would be entirely reasonable that Yellow Fever from
Caracas introduced into, other towns near the end of the Caracas
epidemic should persist in some of them after it had disappeared
from, Caracas itself; indeed, by a similar process, (i.e.l the in-
vasion of new territory), be kept up some years. This seems to
be the most plausible explanation of the method by which the
infection in the towns and large ranches of Yucatan and Campeche
has

has been kept up.

It is on this account that a further examination is
advised of Venezuela in 1917 or 1918 - the first preferably.
If the condition above outlined exists it should, unless it
be disappearing, be then apparent.

It seems also extreemly advisable to investigate the
so-called “Acclimatization Fever” at Maracaibo, which is be-
lieved locally to be a mild kind of Yellow Fever. Not less
advisable is it to make an investigation of the fevers that
prevail in Martinique, as the teachings of some French investi
gators, members of a Commission of the Pasteur Institute, are that in this
island Yellow Fever exists as a permanent infection, gener-
ally in a form so mild as to be negligible, but developing
greater virulence from time to time, in epidemics. This view,
solely I believe on account of the standing of the men who
advance it, is quite generally accepted, explicitly or implic-
itly, in South America, and is applied to many other localities
from which Yellow Fever has apparently disappeared for many
years.
